title: Who was the first Hindu god? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Kavim puraanam anushaasitaaram anoraneeyaam samanu smaredhyaha. Sarvasya dhaataaram achintya roopam aaditya varnam tamasah parastaat.”[Bhagavad Geeta. Ch.VIII.verse 9]. “The one who contemplates on the all-wise, ageless, the ruler of all, subtler than the subtle, the universal sustainer, possessing a form beyond human conception, refulgent like sun and far beyond the darkness of ignorance, attains Him”. “Anoraneeyaan mahato maheeyaan, Aatmaa guhaayaam nihitosya jantoho Tamakratum pashyati veeta shoko dhaatuh prasaadaat mahimaanam eesham.” [Shvetaashvatara upanishad] The Self/God that is subtler than the subtle and greater than the great is residing in the heart of every creature. Through the grace of God, one who sees the Self as desire-less, and sees Its glory as God, becomes sorrow-less. “Veda aham etam ajaram puraanam sarva atmaanam sarva gatam vibhutvaat; Janma nirodham pravadanti yasya Brahmavaadino he pravadanti nityam. “I know this ancient One who is free from decrepitude, who is the Self of all, and who is omnipresent by virtue of pervasiveness; regarding whom the wise speak as birth-less, and whom they speak of as eternal.” Thus the whole of Vedic and Upanishadic thoughts describe God as unborn, formless, indestructible, inscrutable, unchanging, omnipresent, Omnipotent and Omniscient. Then how can you assess the age of something unborn? The entire manifested world is an expression of one ‘Divinity’ in various names and forms! Therefore myself, yourself and the entire world comprising of sentient and insentient is an expression of Divinity/God/Absolute Reality; no matter by which name you call it! “Ghata kalasha kusoola soochi mukhaihi gaganam upaadi shataihi vimuktam ekam. Bhavati na vividham tathaiva shudhdham param aham aadi vimuktam eva.[Viveka chudaamani by Shankaraachaarya] The space inside a pot, urn, barn, needle etc. is same without forms. Similarly, the pure/Supreme Consciousness is same in all of us. One who being confined in a form, transcends the three attributes-Viz Sattva, Rajas and Tamas is considered as the very embodiment/incarnation of Divinity/God. Keeping in view the Dashavatara[ten incarnations of Lord Vishnu] and the Vedic hymns, the following list is prepared. Our ancients were nature worshippers. Therefore, Savitru/Sun, River, Agni/fire, wind/air and earth were ancient gods. Snake worship as symbol of fertility and endurance was also in vogue. Indra, God of rain and thunder, Vishnu, the all pervading aspect of God, Rudra/Pashupati come later. If you consider incarnations of Lord Vishnu, Matsya[fish], Kurma[tortoise], Varaha[wild boar], Narasimha[lion+man], Vamana[dwarf], Parashurama[primitive man], Rama, Krishna, Balarama/Buddha and Kalki are all considered as God. There is also an evolutionary interpretation to this. With the evolution of temple architecture and Agama Shastras, the idol worship gained momentum. With this, the worship of Asta-Dikpalakas also came into vogue. For a non-Hindu, it may appear as if we believe/worship innumerable gods. The fact is, in whatever form a Hindu worships[male/female], the attributes of god and the mode of worship remains the same. In conclusion, birth and death are two faces of the same coin. God is above births and deaths. You can not assess the age of something which is unborn. Therefore, there is neither an old, older, oldest God nor a young, younger, youngest God!
